member.summary: Allows actions to be chained together with the caveat that if Object is null, it is replaced with the DefaultObjectValue specified. If the Action or Object (once replaced with the default object value) is null, it will return the object.
member.param: Object to run the action on
member.returns: The original object

member.name: M:DevGrep.Classes.DataTypes.ExtensionMethods.GenericObjectExtensions.Chain``2(``0,System.Func{``0,``1},``1,``0)
member.summary: Allows actions to be chained together. It also has a couple of checks in there: 1) If the function is null, it returns the default return value specified. 2) If the object is null, it will replace it with the default object value specified. 3) If the object, once replaced with the default object value specified, is null, it will return the default return value specified. 4) If the return value from the function is null, it returns the default return value specified.
member.param: Object to run the action on
member.returns: The result from the function

member.name: T:DevGrep.Classes.IndexedFiles.IndexSearchHelper.OneNormsReader
member.summary: Use the norms from one field for all fields. Norms are read into memory, using a byte of memory per document per searched field. This can cause search of large collections with a large number of fields to run out of memory. If all of the fields contain only a single token, then the norms are all identical, then single norm vector may be shared.

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditAtEdgeBehaviour
member.summary: Indicates the behavior of a key when a cell "on the edge" is being edited. and the normal behavior of that key would exceed the edge. For example, for a key that normally moves one column to the left, the "edge" would be the left most column, since the normal action of the key cannot be taken (since there are no more columns to the left).

member.name: F:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditAtEdgeBehaviour.Ignore
member.summary: The key press will be ignored

member.name: F:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditAtEdgeBehaviour.Wrap
member.summary: The key press will result in the cell editing wrapping to the cell on the opposite edge.

member.name: F:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditAtEdgeBehaviour.ChangeColumn
member.summary: The key press will wrap, but the column will be changed to the appropiate adjacent column. This only makes sense for keys where the normal action is ChangeRow.

member.name: F:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditAtEdgeBehaviour.ChangeRow
member.summary: The key press will wrap, but the row will be changed to the appropiate adjacent row. This only makes sense for keys where the normal action is ChangeColumn.

member.name: F:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditAtEdgeBehaviour.EndEdit
member.summary: The key will result in the current edit operation being ended.

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditCharacterBehaviour
member.summary: Indicates the normal behaviour of a key when used during a cell edit operation.

member.name: F:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditCharacterBehaviour.Ignore
member.summary: The key press will be ignored

member.name: F:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditCharacterBehaviour.ChangeColumnLeft
member.summary: The key press will end the current edit and begin an edit operation on the next editable cell to the left.

member.name: F:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditCharacterBehaviour.ChangeColumnRight

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.DataListView
member.summary: A DataListView is a ListView that can be bound to a datasource (which would normally be a DataTable or DataView).

remarks.para: This listview keeps itself in sync with its source datatable by listening for change events.

If the listview has no columns when given a data source, it will automatically create columns to show all of the datatables columns. This will be only the simplest view of the world, and would look more interesting with a few delegates installed.
This listview will also automatically generate missing aspect getters to fetch the values from the data view.
Changing data sources is possible, but error prone. Before changing data sources, the programmer is responsible for modifying/resetting the column collection to be valid for the new data source.

Internally, a CurrencyManager controls keeping the data source in-sync with other users of the data source (as per normal .NET behavior). This means that the model objects in the DataListView are DataRowView objects. If you write your own AspectGetters/Setters, they will be given DataRowView objects.

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView
member.summary: An ObjectListView is a much easier to use, and much more powerful, version of the ListView.

remarks.para: An ObjectListView automatically populates a ListView control with information taken from a given collection of objects. It can do this because each column is configured to know which bit of the model object (the "aspect") it should be displaying. Columns similarly understand how to sort the list based on their aspect, and how to construct groups using their aspect.

Aspects are extracted by giving the name of a method to be called or a property to be fetched. These names can be simple names or they can be dotted to chain property access e.g. "Owner.Address.Postcode". Aspects can also be extracted by installing a delegate.
An ObjectListView can show a "this list is empty" message when there is nothing to show in the list, so that the user knows the control is supposed to be empty.

Right clicking on a column header should present a menu which can contain: commands (sort, group, ungroup); filtering; and column selection. Whether these parts of the menu appear is controlled by ShowCommandMenuOnRightClick, ShowFilterMenuOnRightClick and SelectColumnsOnRightClick respectively.

The groups created by an ObjectListView can be configured to include other formatting information, including a group icon, subtitle and task button. Using some undocumented interfaces, these groups can even on virtual lists.

ObjectListView supports dragging rows to other places, including other application. Special support is provide for drops from other ObjectListViews in the same application. In many cases, an ObjectListView becomes a full drag source by setting to true. Similarly, to accept drops, it is usually enough to set to true, and then handle the and events (or the and events, if you only want to handle drops from other ObjectListViews in your application).
For these classes to build correctly, the project must have references to these assemblies:

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.ApplyExtendedStyles
member.summary: Apply all required extended styles to our control.

remarks.para: Whenever .NET code sets an extended style, it erases all other extended styles that it doesn't use. So, we have to explicit reapply the styles that we have added.

Normally, we would override CreateParms property and update the ExStyle member, but ListView seems to ignore all ExStyles that it doesn't already know about. Worse, when we set the LVS_EX_HEADERINALLVIEWS value, bad things happen (the control crashes!).

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.SetNativeBackgroundWatermark(System.Drawing.Image)
member.summary: Set the given image to be fixed in the bottom right of the list view. This image will not scroll when the list view scrolls.

remarks.para: This method uses ListView's native ability to display a background image. It has a few limitations:

item.description: It doesn't work well with owner drawn mode. In owner drawn mode, each cell draws itself, including its background, which covers the background image.
It doesn't look very good when grid lines are enabled, since the grid lines are drawn over the image.
It does not work at all on XP.
Obviously, it doesn't look good when alternate row background colors are enabled.

remarks.para: If you can live with these limitations, native watermarks are quite neat. They are true backgrounds, not translucent overlays like the OverlayImage uses. They also have the decided advantage over overlays in that they work correctly even in MDI applications.
Setting this clears any background image.

member.param: The image to be drawn. If null, any existing image will be removed.

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.SetNativeBackgroundImage(System.Drawing.Image,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the given image to be background of the ListView so that it appears at the given percentage offsets within the list.

remarks.para: This has the same limitations as described in . Make sure those limitations are understood before using the method.

This is very similar to setting the property of the standard .NET ListView, except that the standard BackgroundImage does not handle images with transparent areas properly -- it renders transparent areas as black. This method does not have that problem.
Setting this clears any background watermark.

member.param: The image to be drawn. If null, any existing image will be removed.
The horizontal percentage where the image will be placed. 0 is absolute left, 100 is absolute right.
The vertical percentage where the image will be placed.

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.SetNativeBackgroundTiledImage(System.Drawing.Image)
member.summary: Set the given image to be the tiled background of the ListView.

remarks.para: This has the same limitations as described in and . Make sure those limitations are understood before using the method.

member.param: The image to be drawn. If null, any existing image will be removed.

member.summary: Set the collection of objects that will be shown in this list view.
member.remark: This method can safely be called from background threads.
member.remarks: The list is updated immediately
member.param: Should the state of the list be preserved as far as is possible.

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.SaveState
member.summary: Return a byte array that represents the current state of the ObjectListView, such that the state can be restored by RestoreState()

remarks.para:
The state of an ObjectListView includes the attributes that the user can modify:
current view (i.e. Details, Tile, Large Icon...)
sort column and direction
column order
column widths
column visibility
It does not include selection or the scroll position.

member.returns: A byte array representing the state of the ObjectListView

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.RestoreState(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Restore the state of the control from the given string, which must have been produced by SaveState()
member.param: A byte array returned from SaveState()
member.returns: Returns true if the state was restored

member.remarks: We cannot rely on lvi.Index in this method. In a straight list, lvi.Index is the display index, and can be used to determine whether the row should be colored. But when organised by groups, lvi.Index is not useable because it still refers to the position in the overall list, not the display order.

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.TakeOwnershipOfObjects
member.summary: Take ownership of the 'objects' collection. This separats our collection from the source.

remarks.para: This method separates the 'objects' instance variable from its source, so that any AddObject/RemoveObject calls will modify our collection and not the original colleciton.
This method has the intentional side-effect of converting our list of objects to an ArrayList.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.AllColumns
member.summary: Get or set all the columns that this control knows about. Only those columns where IsVisible is true will be seen by the user.

remarks.para: If you want to add new columns programmatically, add them to AllColumns and then call RebuildColumns(). Normally, you do not have to deal with this property directly. Just use the IDE.
If you do add or remove columns from the AllColumns collection, you have to call RebuildColumns() to make those changes take effect.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CellEditActivation
member.summary: How does the user indicate that they want to edit a cell? None means that the listview cannot be edited.
member.remarks: Columns can also be marked as editable.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CellEditKeyEngine
member.summary: Gets or sets the engine that will handle key presses during a cell edit operation. Settings this to null will reset it to default value.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CellEditor
member.summary: Gets the control that is currently being used for editing a cell.
member.remarks: This will obviously be null if no cell is being edited.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CellEditTabChangesRows
member.summary: Gets or sets the behaviour of the Tab key when editing a cell on the left or right edge of the control. If this is false (the default), pressing Tab will wrap to the other side of the same row. If this is true, pressing Tab when editing the right most cell will advance to the next row and Shift-Tab when editing the left-most cell will change to the previous row.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CellEditEnterChangesRows
member.summary: Gets or sets the behaviour of the Enter keys while editing a cell. If this is false (the default), pressing Enter will simply finish the editing operation. If this is true, Enter will finish the edit operation and start a new edit operation on the cell below the current cell, wrapping to the top of the next row when at the bottom cell.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CellToolTip
member.summary: Gets the tool tip control that shows tips for the cells

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CheckBoxes
member.summary: Should this list show checkboxes?

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CheckedObject
member.summary: Return the model object of the row that is checked or null if no row is checked or more than one row is checked

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CheckedObjects
member.summary: Get or set the collection of model objects that are checked. When setting this property, any row whose model object isn't in the given collection will be unchecked. Setting to null is equivilent to unchecking all.

remarks.para: This property returns a simple collection. Changes made to the returned collection do NOT affect the list. This is different to the behaviour of CheckedIndicies collection.
.NET's CheckedItems property is not helpful. It is just a short-hand for iterating through the list looking for items that are checked.

The performance of the get method is O(n), where n is the number of items in the control. The performance of the set method is O(n + m) where m is the number of objects being checked. Be careful on long lists.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CheckedObjectsEnumerable
member.summary: Gets or sets the checked objects from an enumerable.
member.remarks: Useful for checking all objects in the list.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.Columns
member.summary: Gets Columns for this list. We hide the original so we can associate a specialised editor with it.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.ColumnsForTileView
member.summary: Get/set the list of columns that should be used when the list switches to tile view.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.ColumnsInDisplayOrder
member.summary: Return the visible columns in the order they are displayed to the user

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.ContentRectangle
member.summary: Get the area of the control that shows the list, minus any header control

A decoration scrolls with the list contents. An overlay is fixed in place.

remarks.para: If the given sink is an instance of SimpleDropSink, then events from the drop sink will be automatically forwarded to the ObjectListView (which means that handlers for those event can be configured within the IDE).
If this is set to null, the control will not accept drops.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.FilteredObjects

member.summary: Gets or sets the font in which the text of the column headers will be drawn
member.remarks: Individual columns can override this through their HeaderFormatStyle property.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.HeaderFormatStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the style that will be used to draw the columm headers of the listview

remarks.para: This is only used when HeaderUsesThemes is false.
Individual columns can override this through their HeaderFormatStyle property.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.HeaderMaximumHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum height of the header. -1 means no maximum.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.HeaderUsesThemes
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the header will be drawn strictly according to the OS's theme.

remarks.para: If this is set to true, the header will be rendered completely by the system, without any of ObjectListViews fancy processing -- no images in header, no filter indicators, no word wrapping, no header styling.

If this is set to false, ObjectListView will render the header as it thinks best. If no special features are required, then ObjectListView will delegate rendering to the OS. Otherwise, ObjectListView will draw the header according to the configuration settings.
The effect of not being themed will be different from OS to OS. At very least, the sort indicator will not be standard.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.HeaderWordWrap
member.summary: Gets or sets the whether the text in the header will be word wrapped.

remarks.para: THIS FEATURE IS EXPERIMENTAL (August 2009)
Line breaks will be applied between words. Words that are too long will still be ellipsed.
As with all settings that make the header look different, HeaderUsesThemes must be set to false, otherwise the OS will be responsible for drawing the header, and it does not allow word wrapped text.

member.summary: Gets the hit test info last time the mouse was moved.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.OLVGroups
member.summary: Gets or sets the list of groups shown by the listview.
member.remarks: This property does not work like the .NET Groups property. It should be treated as a read-only property. Changes made to the list are NOT reflected in the ListView itself -- it is pointless to add or remove groups to/from this list. Such modifications will do nothing. To do such things, you must listen for BeforeCreatingGroups or AboutToCreateGroups events, and change the list of groups in those events.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.OwnerDrawnHeader
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user wants to owner draw the header control themselves. If this is false (the default), ObjectListView will use custom drawing to render the header, if needed.
member.remarks: If you listen for the DrawColumnHeader event, you need to set this to true, otherwise your event handler will not be called.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.Objects
member.summary: Get/set the collection of objects that this list will show

remarks.para: The contents of the control will be updated immediately after setting this property.

This method preserves selection, if possible. Use SetObjects() if you do not want to preserve the selection. Preserving selection is the slowest part of this code and performance is O(n) where n is the number of selected rows.
This method is not thread safe.
The property DOES work on virtual lists: setting is problem-free, but if you try to get it and the list has 10 million objects, it may take some time to return.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.OverlayImage

member.remarks: This is obsolete. Use Transparency on each overlay.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.Overlays
member.summary: Gets the list of overlays that will be drawn on top of the ListView
member.remarks: You can add new overlays and remove overlays that you have added, but don't mess with the overlays that you didn't create.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.RowHeight
member.summary: Specify the height of each row in the control in pixels.

remarks.para: The row height in a listview is normally determined by the font size and the small image list size. This setting allows that calculation to be overridden (within reason: you still cannot set the line height to be less than the line height of the font used in the control).
Setting it to -1 means use the normal calculation method.
This feature is experiemental! Strange things may happen to your program, your spouse or your pet if you use it.

The colour of the tint is controlled by SelectedColumnTint.

member.summary: Gets or sets the decoration that will be drawn on all selected rows

member.summary: Gets or sets the index of the row that is currently selected. When getting the index, if no row is selected,or more than one is selected, return -1.

member.summary: Gets or sets the ListViewItem that is currently selected . If no row is selected, or more than one is selected, return null.

member.summary: Gets the model object from the currently selected row, if there is only one row selected. If no row is selected, or more than one is selected, returns null. When setting, this will select the row that is displaying the given model object and focus on it. All other rows are deselected.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.SelectedObjects
member.summary: Get the model objects from the currently selected rows. If no row is selected, the returned List will be empty. When setting this value, select the rows that is displaying the given model objects. All other rows are deselected.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.ShowCommandMenuOnRightClick
member.summary: When the user right clicks on the column headers, should a menu be presented which will allow them to choose common tasks to perform on the listview?

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.ShowFilterMenuOnRightClick
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this ObjectListView will show Excel like filtering menus when the header control is right clicked

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.ShowGroups
member.summary: Should this list show its items in groups?

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.ShowSortIndicators
member.summary: Should the list view show a bitmap in the column header to show the sort direction?
member.remarks: The only reason for not wanting to have sort indicators is that, on pre-XP versions of Windows, having sort indicators required the ListView to have a small image list, and as soon as you give a ListView a SmallImageList, the text of column 0 is bumped 16 pixels to the right, even if you never used an image.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.ShowImagesOnSubItems
member.summary: Should the list view show images on subitems?

remarks.para: Virtual lists have to be owner drawn in order to show images on subitems

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.ShowItemCountOnGroups
member.summary: This property controls whether group labels will be suffixed with a count of items.
member.remarks: The format of the suffix is controlled by GroupWithItemCountFormat/GroupWithItemCountSingularFormat properties

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.ShowHeaderInAllViews
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the control will show column headers in all views (true), or only in Details view (false)

remarks.para: This property is not working correctly. JPP 2010/04/06. It works fine if it is set before the control is created. But if it turned off once the control is created, the control loses its checkboxes (weird!)

To changed this setting after the control is created, things are complicated. If it is off and we want it on, we have to change the View and the header will appear. If it is currently on and we want to turn it off, we have to both change the view AND recreate the handle. Recreating the handle is a problem since it makes our checkbox style disappear.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.SmallImageList
member.summary: Override the SmallImageList property so we can correctly shadow its operations.

remarks.para: If you use the RowHeight property to specify the row height, the SmallImageList must be fully initialised before setting/changing the RowHeight. If you add new images to the image list after setting the RowHeight, you must assign the imagelist to the control again. Something as simple as this will work: listView1.SmallImageList = listView1.SmallImageList;

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.SmallImageSize
member.summary: Return the size of the images in the small image list or a reasonable default

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.SortGroupItemsByPrimaryColumn
member.summary: When the listview is grouped, should the items be sorted by the primary column? If this is false, the items will be sorted by the same column as they are grouped.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.SpaceBetweenGroups
member.summary: When the listview is grouped, how many pixels should exist between the end of one group and the beginning of the next?

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.TintSortColumn
member.summary: Should the sort column show a slight tinge?

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.TriStateCheckBoxes
member.summary: Should each row have a tri-state checkbox?
member.remarks: If this is true, the user can choose the third state (normally Indeterminate). Otherwise, user clicks alternate between checked and unchecked. CheckStateGetter can still return Indeterminate when this setting is false.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.TopItemIndex
member.summary: Get or set the index of the top item of this listview

remarks.para: This property only works when the listview is in Details view and not showing groups.
The reason that it does not work when showing groups is that, when groups are enabled, the Windows msg LVM_GETTOPINDEX always returns 0, regardless of the scroll position.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UpdateSpaceFillingColumnsWhenDraggingColumnDivider
member.summary: When resizing a column by dragging its divider, should any space filling columns be resized at each mouse move? If this is false, the filling columns will be updated when the mouse is released.

remarks.para: In previous versions, setting this to true produced ugly behaviour, because every column to the right of the divider being dragged was updated twice: once when the column be resized changes size (this moves all the columns slightly to the right); then again when the filling columns are updated - they are shrunk so that the combined width is not more than the control, so everything jumps slightly back to the left again.
But, as of v2.0, the change the Windows messages in place, so there is now only one update, and everything looks nice and smooth.

However, it still looks odd when the space filling column is in the left of the column that is being resized: the right edge of the column is dragged, but its left edge moves, since the space filling column is shrinking.
Given the above behavior is probably best to turn this property off if your space filling columns aren't the right-most columns.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UnfocusedHighlightBackgroundColor
member.summary: What color should be used for the background of selected rows when the control doesn't have the focus?
member.remarks: Windows does not give the option of changing the selection background. So the control has to be owner drawn to see the result of this setting. Setting UseCustomSelectionColors = true will do this for you.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UnfocusedHighlightBackgroundColorOrDefault
member.summary: Return the color should be used for the background of selected rows when the control doesn't have the focus or a reasonable default

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UnfocusedHighlightForegroundColor
member.summary: What color should be used for the foreground of selected rows when the control doesn't have the focus?
member.remarks: Windows does not give the option of changing the selection foreground (text color). So the control has to be owner drawn to see the result of this setting. Setting UseCustomSelectionColors = true will do this for you.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UnfocusedHighlightForegroundColorOrDefault
member.summary: Return the color should be used for the foreground of selected rows when the control doesn't have the focus or a reasonable default

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UseAlternatingBackColors
member.summary: Should the list give a different background color to every second row?

remarks.para: The color of the alternate rows is given by AlternateRowBackColor.
There is a "feature" in .NET for listviews in non-full-row-select mode, where selected rows are not drawn with their correct background color.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UseCellFormatEvents
member.summary: Should FormatCell events be called for each cell in the control?
member.remarks: Individual rows can decide whether to call FormatCell events. This is simply the default behaviour.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UseCustomSelectionColors
member.summary: Should the selected row be drawn with non-standard foreground and background colors?
member.remarks: When this is enabled, the control becomes owner drawn.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UseExplorerTheme
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this ObjectListView will use the same hot item and selection mechanism that Vista Explorer does.
member.remarks:
This property has many imperfections:
This only works on Vista and later
It does nothing for owner drawn lists. Owner drawn lists are (naturally) controlled by their renderers.
It does not work well with AlternateRowBackColors.
It does not play well with HotItemStyles.
It looks a little bit silly is FullRowSelect is false.
But if you absolutely have to look like Vista, this is your property. Do not complain if settings this messes up other things.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UseFiltering
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the list should enable filtering

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UseFilterIndicator
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the list should put an indicator into a column's header to show that it is filtering on that column

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UseHotItem
member.summary: Should the item under the cursor be formatted in a special way?

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UseHyperlinks
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this listview should show hyperlinks in the cells.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UseOverlays
member.summary: Should this control show overlays
member.remarks: Overlays are enabled by default and would only need to be disabled if they were causing problems in your development environment.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UseSubItemCheckBoxes
member.summary: Should this control be configured to show check boxes on subitems?
member.remarks: If this is set to True, the control will be given a SmallImageList if it doesn't already have one. Also, if it is a virtual list, it will be set to owner drawn, since virtual lists can't draw check boxes without being owner drawn.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UseTranslucentSelection
member.summary: Gets or sets if the ObjectListView will use a translucent selection mechanism like Vista.

remarks.para: Unlike UseExplorerTheme, this Vista-like scheme works on XP and for both owner and non-owner drawn lists.
This will replace any SelectedRowDecoration that has been installed.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.UseTranslucentHotItem
member.summary: Gets or sets if the ObjectListView will use a translucent hot row highlighting mechanism like Vista.
member.remarks: Setting this will replace any HotItemStyle that has been

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.View
member.summary: Get/set the style of view that this listview is using
member.remarks: Switching to tile or details view installs the columns appropriate to that view. Confusingly, in tile view, every column is shown as a row of information.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.BooleanCheckStateGetter
member.summary: This delegate fetches the checkedness of an object as a boolean only.
member.remarks:
Use this if you never want to worry about the Indeterminate state (which is fairly common).
This is a convenience wrapper around the CheckStateGetter property.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.BooleanCheckStatePutter
member.summary: This delegate sets the checkedness of an object as a boolean only. It must return true or false indicating if the object was checked or not.
member.remarks:
Use this if you never want to worry about the Indeterminate state (which is fairly common).
This is a convenience wrapper around the CheckStatePutter property.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CanShowGroups
member.summary: Gets whether or not this listview is capabale of showing groups

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CellToolTipGetter
member.summary: This delegate is called when the list wants to show a tooltip for a particular cell. The delegate should return the text to display, or null to use the default behavior (which is to show the full text of truncated cell values).
member.remarks: Displaying the full text of truncated cell values only work for FullRowSelect listviews. This is MS's behavior, not mine. Don't complain to me :)

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CheckedAspectName
member.summary: The name of the property (or field) that holds whether or not a model is checked.

remarks.para: The property be modifiable. It must have a return type of bool (or of bool? if TriStateCheckBoxes is true).

Setting this property replaces any CheckStateGetter or CheckStatePutter that have been installed. Conversely, later setting the CheckStateGetter or CheckStatePutter properties will take precedence over the behavior of this property.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CheckStateGetter
member.summary: This delegate will be called whenever the ObjectListView needs to know the check state of the row associated with a given model object.

remarks.para: .NET has no support for indeterminate values, but as of v2.0, this class allows indeterminate values.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CheckStatePutter
member.summary: This delegate will be called whenever the user tries to change the check state of a row. The delegate should return the state that was actually set, which may be different to the state given.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CustomSorter
member.summary: This delegate can be used to sort the table in a custom fasion.

remarks.para: The delegate must install a ListViewItemSorter on the ObjectListView. Installing the ItemSorter does the actual work of sorting the ListViewItems. See ColumnComparer in the code for an example of what an ItemSorter has to do.
Do not install a CustomSorter on a VirtualObjectListView. Override the SortObjects() method of the IVirtualListDataSource instead.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.HeaderToolTipGetter
member.summary: This delegate is called when the list wants to show a tooltip for a particular header. The delegate should return the text to display, or null to use the default behavior (which is to not show any tooltip).
member.remarks: Installing a HeaderToolTipGetter takes precedence over any text in OLVColumn.ToolTipText.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.RowFormatter
member.summary: This delegate can be used to format a OLVListItem before it is added to the control.

remarks.para: The model object for the row can be found through the RowObject property of the OLVListItem object.

All subitems normally have the same style as list item, so setting the forecolor on one subitem changes the forecolor of all subitems. To allow subitems to have different attributes, do this: myListViewItem.UseItemStyleForSubItems = false;.

If UseAlternatingBackColors is true, the backcolor of the listitem will be calculated by the control and cannot be controlled by the RowFormatter delegate. In general, trying to use a RowFormatter when UseAlternatingBackColors is true does not work well.

As it says in the summary, this is called before the item is added to the control. Many properties of the OLVListItem itself are not available at that point, including: Index, Selected, Focused, Bounds, Checked, DisplayIndex.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.MenuLabelSortAscending
member.summary: Gets or set the text to be used for the sorting ascending command

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CellEditActivateMode
member.summary: How does a user indicate that they want to edit cells?

member.name: F:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CellEditActivateMode.None
member.summary: This list cannot be edited. F2 does nothing.

member.name: F:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CellEditActivateMode.SingleClick
member.summary: A single click on a subitem will edit the value. Single clicking the primary column, selects the row just like normal. The user must press F2 to edit the primary column.

member.name: F:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CellEditActivateMode.DoubleClick
member.summary: Double clicking a subitem or the primary column will edit that cell. F2 will edit the primary column.

member.name: F:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView.CellEditActivateMode.F2Only
member.summary: Pressing F2 is the only way to edit the cells. Once the primary column is being edited, the other cells in the row can be edited by pressing Tab.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.DataListView.DataSource
member.summary: Get or set the VirtualListDataSource that will be displayed in this list view.
member.remarks:
The VirtualListDataSource should implement either , , or . Some common examples are the following types of objects:
When binding to a list container (i.e. one that implements the interface, such as ) you must also set the property in order to identify which particular list you would like to display. You may also set the property even when VirtualListDataSource refers to a list, since can also be used to navigate relations between lists.

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.IDragSource
member.summary: An IDragSource controls how drag out from the ObjectListView will behave

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.IDragSource.StartDrag(DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ObjectListView,System.Windows.Forms.MouseButtons,DevGrep.Controls.DLV.OLVListItem)
member.summary: A drag operation is beginning. Return the data object that will be used for data transfer. Return null to prevent the drag from starting. The data object will normally include all the selected objects.
member.remarks: The returned object is later passed to the GetAllowedEffect() and EndDrag() methods.
member.param: What ObjectListView is being dragged from.
What item was directly dragged by the user? There may be more than just this item selected.
member.returns: The data object that will be used for data transfer. This will often be a subclass of DataObject, but does not need to be.

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.IDragSource.GetAllowedEffects(System.Object)
member.summary: What operations are possible for this drag? This controls the icon shown during the drag
member.param: The data object returned by StartDrag()
member.returns: A combination of DragDropEffects flags

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.IDragSource.EndDrag(System.Object,System.Windows.Forms.DragDropEffects)
member.summary: The drag operation is complete. Do whatever is necessary to complete the action.
member.param: The data object returned by StartDrag()

member.summary: A do-nothing implementation of IDragSource that can be safely subclassed.

member.summary: See IDragSource documentation

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.SimpleDragSource
member.summary: A reasonable implementation of IDragSource that provides normal drag source functionality. It creates a data object that supports inter-application dragging of text and HTML representation of the dragged rows. It can optionally force a refresh of all dragged rows when the drag is complete.
member.remarks: Subclasses can override GetDataObject() to add new data formats to the data transfer object.

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.RearrangingDropSink
member.summary: This drop sink allows items within the same list to be rearranged, as well as allowing items to be dropped from other lists.

remarks.para: This class can only be used on plain ObjectListViews and FastObjectListViews. The other flavours have no way to implement the insert operation that is required.
This class does not work with grouping.

This class works when the OLV is sorted, but it is up to the programmer to decide what rearranging such lists "means". Example: if the control is sorting students by academic grade, and the user drags a "Fail" grade student up amonst the "A+" students, it is the responsibility of the programmer to makes the appropriate changes to the model and redraw/rebuild the control so that the users action makes sense.
Users of this class should listen for the CanDrop event to decide if models from another OLV can be moved to OLV under this sink.

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.FastDataListView
member.summary: A FastDataListView virtualizes the display of data from a DataSource. It operates on DataSets and DataTables in the same way as a DataListView, but does so much more efficiently.

remarks.para: A FastDataListView still has to load all its data from the DataSource. If you have SQL statement that returns 1 million rows, all 1 million rows will still need to read from the database. However, once the rows are loaded, the FastDataListView will only build rows as they are displayed.

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.FastObjectListView
member.summary: A FastObjectListView trades function for speed.

remarks.para: On my mid-range laptop, this view builds a list of 10,000 objects in 0.1 seconds, as opposed to a normal ObjectListView which takes 10-15 seconds. Lists of up to 50,000 items should be able to be handled with sub-second response times even on low end machines.

A FastObjectListView is implemented as a virtual list with many of the virtual modes limits (e.g. no sorting) fixed through coding. There are some functions that simply cannot be provided. Specifically, a FastObjectListView cannot:
use Tile view
show groups on XP

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.VirtualObjectListView
member.summary: A virtual object list view operates in virtual mode, that is, it only gets model objects for a row when it is needed. This gives it the ability to handle very large numbers of rows with minimal resources.

remarks.para: A listview is not a great user interface for a large number of items. But if you've ever wanted to have a list with 10 million items, go ahead, knock yourself out.
Virtual lists can never iterate their contents. That would defeat the whole purpose.

Animated GIFs should not be used in virtual lists. Animated GIFs require some state information to be stored for each animation, but virtual lists specifically do not keep any state information. In any case, you really do not want to keep state information for 10 million animations!

Although it isn't documented, .NET virtual lists cannot have checkboxes. This class codes around this limitation, but you must use the functions provided by ObjectListView: CheckedObjects, CheckObject(), UncheckObject() and their friends. If you use the normal check box properties (CheckedItems or CheckedIndicies), they will throw an exception, since the list is in virtual mode, and .NET "knows" it can't handle checkboxes in virtual mode.
The "CheckBoxes" property itself can be set once, but trying to unset it later will throw an exception.
Due to the limits of the underlying Windows control, virtual lists do not trigger ItemCheck/ItemChecked events. Use a CheckStatePutter instead.
To enable grouping, you must provide an implmentation of IVirtualGroups interface, via the GroupingStrategy property.
Similarly, to enable filtering on the list, your VirtualListDataSource must also implement the IFilterableDataSource interface.

member.summary: Remove all of the given objects from the control
member.param: Collection of objects to be removed

remarks.para: Nulls and model objects that are not in the ListView are silently ignored.

Due to problems in the underlying ListView, if you remove all the objects from the control using this method and the list scroll vertically when you do so, then when you subsequenially add more objects to the control, the vertical scroll bar will become confused and the control will draw one or more blank lines at the top of the list.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.VirtualObjectListView.CheckedObjects
member.summary: Get or set the collection of model objects that are checked. When setting this property, any row whose model object isn't in the given collection will be unchecked. Setting to null is equivilent to unchecking all.

remarks.para: This property returns a simple collection. Changes made to the returned collection do NOT affect the list. This is different to the behaviour of CheckedIndicies collection.

When getting CheckedObjects, the performance of this method is O(n) where n is the number of checked objects. When setting CheckedObjects, the performance of this method is O(n) where n is the number of checked objects plus the number of objects to be checked.
If the ListView is not currently showing CheckBoxes, this property does nothing. It does not remember any check box settings made.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.VirtualObjectListView.Objects
member.summary: Get/set the collection of objects that this list will show

remarks.para: The contents of the control will be updated immediately after setting this property.

Setting this property preserves selection, if possible. Use SetObjects() if you do not want to preserve the selection. Preserving selection is the slowest part of this code -- performance is O(n) where n is the number of selected rows.
This method is not thread safe.
The property DOES work on virtual lists, but if you try to iterate through a list of 10 million objects, it may take some time :)

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ClusteringStrategy.DefaultDisplayLabelFormatSingular
member.summary: Gets or sets the format that will be used by default for clusters that only contain 1 item. The format string must accept two placeholders: - {0} is the cluster key converted to a string - {1} is the number of items in the cluster (always 1 in this case)

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ClusteringStrategy.DefaultDisplayLabelFormatPlural
member.summary: Gets or sets the format that will be used by default for clusters that contain 0 or two or more items. The format string must accept two placeholders: - {0} is the cluster key converted to a string - {1} is the number of items in the cluster

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ClusteringStrategy.Column
member.summary: Gets or sets the column upon which this strategy is operating

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ClusteringStrategy.DisplayLabelFormatSingular
member.summary: Gets or sets the format that will be used when the cluster contains only 1 item. The format string must accept two placeholders: - {0} is the cluster key converted to a string - {1} is the number of items in the cluster (always 1 in this case)
member.remarks: If this is not set, the value from ClusteringStrategy.DefaultDisplayLabelFormatSingular will be used

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ClusteringStrategy.DisplayLabelFormatPlural
member.summary: Gets or sets the format that will be used when the cluster contains 0 or two or more items. The format string must accept two placeholders: - {0} is the cluster key converted to a string - {1} is the number of items in the cluster
member.remarks: If this is not set, the value from ClusteringStrategy.DefaultDisplayLabelFormatPlural will be used

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ClustersFromGroupsStrategy
member.summary: This class calculates clusters from the groups that the column uses.

remarks.para: This is the default strategy for all non-date, filterable columns.

This class does not strictly mimic the groups created by the given column. In particular, if the programmer changes the default grouping technique by listening for grouping events, this class will not mimic that behaviour.

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.TreeListView
member.summary: A TreeListView combines an expandable tree structure with list view columns.

remarks.para: To support tree operations, two delegates must be provided:

item.description: This delegate must accept a model object and return a boolean indicating if that model should be expandable.

This delegate must accept a model object and return an IEnumerable of model objects that will be displayed as children of the parent model. This delegate will only be called for a model object if the CanExpandGetter has already returned true for that model.

remarks.para: The top level branches of the tree are set via the Roots property. SetObjects(), AddObjects() and RemoveObjects() are interpreted as operations on this collection of roots.
To add new children to an existing branch, make changes to your model objects and then call RefreshObject() on the parent.

The tree must be a directed acyclic graph -- no cycles are allowed. Put more mundanely, each model object must appear only once in the tree. If the same model object appears in two places in the tree, the control will become confused.

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.BaseRenderer.DrawTextGdi(System.Drawing.Graphics,System.Drawing.Rectangle,System.String)
member.summary: Print the given text in the given rectangle using only GDI routines
member.remarks:
The native list control uses GDI routines to do its drawing, so using them here makes the owner drawn mode looks more natural.
This method doesn't honour the CanWrap setting on the renderer. All text is single line

member.remarks: Printing to a printer dc has to be done using this method.

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditEventArgs
member.summary: Let the world know that a cell edit operation is beginning or ending

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditEventArgs.#ctor(DevGrep.Controls.DLV.OLVColumn,System.Windows.Forms.Control,System.Drawing.Rectangle,DevGrep.Controls.DLV.OLVListItem,System.Int32)
member.summary: Create an event args

member.name: F:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditEventArgs.Cancel
member.summary: Change this to true to cancel the cell editing operation.

remarks.para: During the CellEditStarting event, setting this to true will prevent the cell from being edited.

During the CellEditFinishing event, if this value is already true, this indicates that the user has cancelled the edit operation and that the handler should perform cleanup only. Setting this to true, will prevent the ObjectListView from trying to write the new value into the model object.

member.name: F:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditEventArgs.Control
member.summary: During the CellEditStarting event, this can be modified to be the control that you want to edit the value. You must fully configure the control before returning from the event, including its bounds and the value it is showing. During the CellEditFinishing event, you can use this to get the value that the user entered and commit that value to the model. Changing the control during the finishing event has no effect.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditEventArgs.Column
member.summary: The column of the cell that is going to be or has been edited.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditEventArgs.RowObject
member.summary: The model object of the row of the cell that is going to be or has been edited.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.CellEditEventArgs.ListViewItem

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.OLVGroup
member.summary: Instances of this class enhance the capabilities of a normal ListViewGroup, enabling the functionality that was released in v6 of the common controls.

remarks.para: In this implementation (2009-09), these objects are essentially passive. Setting properties does not automatically change the associated group in the listview. Collapsed and Collapsible are two exceptions to this and give immediate results.
This really should be a subclass of ListViewGroup, but that class is sealed (why is that?). So this class provides the same interface as a ListViewGroup, plus many other new properties.

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.Munger
member.summary: An instance of Munger gets a value from or puts a value into a target object. The property to be peeked (or poked) is determined from a string. The peeking or poking is done using reflection.
member.remarks:
Name of the aspect to be peeked can be a field, property or parameterless method. The name of an aspect to poke can be a field, writable property or single parameter method.
Aspect names can be dotted to chain a series of references.
Order.Customer.HomeAddress.State

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.Munger.#ctor
member.summary: Create a do nothing Munger

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.Munger.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Create a Munger that works on the given aspect name

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.Munger.PutProperty(System.Object,System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: A helper method to put the given value into the given aspect of the given object.
member.remarks: This method catches and silently ignores any errors that occur while modifying the target object
member.param: The name of the property/field to be modified
member.returns: Did the modification work?

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.Munger.GetValue(System.Object)
member.summary: Extract the value indicated by our AspectName from the given target.
member.remarks: If the aspect name is null or empty, this will return null.
member.param: The object that will be peeked
member.returns: The value read from the target

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.Munger.PutValue(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Poke the given value into the given target indicated by our AspectName.

remarks.para: If the AspectName is a dotted path, all the selectors bar the last are used to find the object that should be updated, and the last selector is used as the property to update on that object.
So, if 'target' is a Person and the AspectName is "HomeAddress.Postcode", this method will first fetch "HomeAddress" property, and then try to set the "Postcode" property on the home address object.

member.param: The object that will be poked
The value that will be poked into the target
member.returns: bool indicating whether the put worked

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.Munger.BuildParts(System.String)
member.summary: Convert a possibly dotted AspectName into a list of SimpleMungers

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.Munger.EvaluateParts(System.Object,System.Collections.Generic.IList{DevGrep.Controls.DLV.SimpleMunger})
member.summary: Evaluate the given chain of SimpleMungers against an initial target.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.Munger.AspectName
member.summary: The name of the aspect that is to be peeked or poked.

remarks.para: This name can be a field, property or parameter-less method.
The name can be dotted, which chains references. If any link in the chain returns null, the entire chain is considered to return null.

member.summary: Gets the list of SimpleMungers that match our AspectName

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.SimpleMunger
member.summary: A SimpleMunger deals with a single property/field/method on its target.
member.remarks: Munger uses a chain of these resolve a dotted aspect name.

member.summary: Create a SimpleMunger

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.SimpleMunger.GetValue(System.Object)
member.summary: Get a value from the given target

member.summary: Poke the given value into the given target indicated by our AspectName.
member.param: The object that will be poked
The value that will be poked into the target
member.returns: bool indicating if the put worked

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.SimpleMunger.AspectName
member.summary: The name of the aspect that is to be peeked or poked.

remarks.para: This name can be a field, property or method. When using a method to get a value, the method must be parameter-less. When using a method to set a value, the method must accept 1 parameter.
It cannot be a dotted name.

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.NativeMethods.SetBackgroundImage(System.Windows.Forms.ListView,System.Drawing.Image,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Put an image under the ListView.

remarks.para: The ListView must have its handle created before calling this.
This doesn't work very well. Specifically, it doesn't play well with owner drawn, and grid lines are drawn over it.

member.param: The image to be used as the background. If this is null, any existing background image will be cleared.
If this is true, the image is pinned to the bottom right and does not scroll. The other parameters are ignored
If this is true, the image will be tiled to fill the whole control background. The offset parameters will be ignored.
If both watermark and tiled are false, this indicates the horizontal percentage where the image will be placed. 0 is absolute left, 100 is absolute right.
If both watermark and tiled are false, this indicates the vertical percentage where the image will be placed.

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.OLVColumn
member.summary: An OLVColumn knows which aspect of an object it should present.
member.remarks:
The column knows how to:
extract its aspect from the row object
convert an aspect to a string
calculate the image for the row object
extract a group "key" from the row object
convert a group "key" into a title for the group
For sorting to work correctly, aspects from the same column must be of the same type, that is, the same aspect cannot sometimes return strings and other times integers.

member.summary: Create groupies

member.summary: Create groupies

member.summary: Create groupies

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.OLVColumn.MakeGroupies``1(``0[],System.String[],System.Object[],System.String[],System.String[])
member.summary: Create groupies. Install delegates that will group the columns aspects into progressive partitions. If an aspect is less than value[n], it will be grouped with description[n]. If an aspect has a value greater than the last element in "values", it will be grouped with the last element in "descriptions".
member.param: Array of values. Values must be able to be compared to the aspect (using IComparable)
The description for the matching value. The last element is the default description. If there are n values, there must be n+1 descriptions.

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.OLVColumn.MakeEqualGroupies``1(``0[],System.String[],System.Object[],System.String[],System.String[])
member.summary: Create groupies based on exact value matches.
member.remarks: Install delegates that will group rows into partitions based on equality of this columns aspects. If an aspect is equal to value[n], it will be grouped with description[n]. If an aspect is not equal to any value, it will be grouped with "[other]".
member.param: Array of values. Values must be able to be equated to the aspect
The description for the matching value.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.OLVColumn.ClusteringStrategy
member.summary: Gets or sets the clustering strategy used for this column.

remarks.para: The clustering strategy is used to build a Filtering menu for this item. If this is null, a useful default will be chosen.
To disable filtering on this colummn, set UseFiltering to false.
Cluster strategies belong to a particular column. The same instance cannot be shared between multiple columns.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.OLVColumn.FillsFreeSpace
member.summary: Should this column resize to fill the free space in the listview?

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.OLVColumn.FreeSpaceProportion
member.summary: What proportion of the unoccupied horizontal space in the control should be given to this column?

remarks.para: There are situations where it would be nice if a column (normally the rightmost one) would expand as the list view expands, so that as much of the column was visible as possible without having to scroll horizontally (you should never, ever make your users have to scroll anything horizontally!).

A space filling column is resized to occupy a proportion of the unoccupied width of the listview (the unoccupied width is the width left over once all the the non-filling columns have been given their space). This property indicates the relative proportion of that unoccupied space that will be given to this column. The actual value of this property is not important -- only its value relative to the value in other columns. For example:
If there is only one space filling column, it will be given all the free space, regardless of the value in FreeSpaceProportion.
If there are two or more space filling columns and they all have the same value for FreeSpaceProportion, they will share the free space equally.
If there are three space filling columns with values of 3, 2, and 1 for FreeSpaceProportion, then the first column with occupy half the free space, the second will occupy one-third of the free space, and the third column one-sixth of the free space.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.OLVColumn.Groupable
member.summary: Gets or sets whether groups will be rebuild on this columns values when this column's header is clicked.

remarks.para: This setting is only used when ShowGroups is true.

If this is false, clicking the header will not rebuild groups. It will not provide any feedback as to why the list is not being regrouped. It is the programmers responsibility to provide appropriate feedback.
When this is false, BeforeCreatingGroups events are still fired, which can be used to allow grouping or give feedback, on a case by case basis.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.OLVColumn.GroupFormatter
member.summary: This delegate is called when a group has been created but not yet made into a real ListViewGroup. The user can take this opportunity to fill in lots of other details about the group.

member.summary: When the listview is grouped by this column and group title has an item count, how should the lable be formatted?
member.remarks:
The given format string can/should have two placeholders:
{0} - the original group title
{1} - the number of items in the group

member.summary: This is the name of property that will be invoked to get the image selector of the image that should be shown in this column. It can return an int, string, Image or null.

remarks.para: This is ignored if ImageGetter is not null.

member.name: P:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.OLVColumn.LastDisplayIndex
member.summary: Where was this column last positioned within the Detail view columns
member.remarks: DisplayIndex is volatile. Once a column is removed from the control, there is no way to discover where it was in the display order. This property guards that information even when the column is not in the listview's active columns.

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.GraphicAdornment.CalculateAlignedPosition(System.Drawing.Point,System.Drawing.Size,System.Drawing.ContentAlignment)
member.summary: Calculate the location of rectangle of the given size, so that it's indicated corner would be at the given point.
member.param: Which corner will be positioned at the reference point
member.example: CalculateAlignedPosition(new Point(50, 100), new Size(10, 20), System.Drawing.ContentAlignment.TopLeft) -> Point(50, 100)

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.GraphicAdornment.CreateAlignedRectangle(System.Drawing.Rectangle,System.Drawing.Size)
member.summary: Calculate a rectangle that has the given size which is positioned so that its alignment point is at the reference location of the given rect.

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.GraphicAdornment.CreateAlignedRectangle(System.Drawing.Rectangle,System.Drawing.Size,System.Drawing.ContentAlignment,System.Drawing.ContentAlignment,System.Drawing.Size)
member.summary: Create a rectangle of the given size which is positioned so that its indicated corner is at the indicated corner of the reference rect.

remarks.para: Creates a rectangle so that its bottom left is at the centre of the reference: corner=BottomLeft, referenceCorner=MiddleCenter
This is a powerful concept that takes some getting used to, but is very neat once you understand it.

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.GraphicAdornment.CalculateCorner(System.Drawing.Rectangle,System.Drawing.ContentAlignment)
member.summary: Return the point at the indicated corner of the given rectangle (it doesn't have to be a corner, but a named location)
member.param: Which point of the rectangle should be returned?
member.returns: A point

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ImageRenderer
member.summary: Render an image that comes from our data source.
member.remarks:
The image can be sourced from:
a byte-array (normally when the image to be shown is stored as a value in a database)
an int, which is treated as an index into the image list
a string, which is treated first as a file name, and failing that as an index into the image list
an ICollection of ints or strings, which will be drawn as consecutive images
If an image is an animated GIF, it's state is stored in the SubItem object.
By default, the image renderer does not render animations (it begins life with animations paused). To enable animations, you must call Unpause().
In the current implementation (2009-09), each column showing animated gifs must have a different instance of ImageRenderer assigned to it. You cannot share the same instance of an image renderer between two animated gif columns. If you do, only the last column will be animated.

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ImageRenderer.#ctor

member.summary: Draw our image

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ImageRenderer.GetImageFromAspect
member.summary: Translate our Aspect into an image.
member.remarks:
The strategy is:
If its a byte array, we treat it as an in-memory image
If it's an int, we use that as an index into our image list
If it's a string, we try to load a file by that name. If we can't, we use the string as an index into our image list.
member.returns: An image

member.name: M:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ImageRenderer.OnTimerInThread
member.summary: This is the OnTimer callback, but invoked in the same thread as the creator of the ListView. This method can use all of ListViews methods without creating a CrossThread exception.

This class is experimental. It may not work properly and may disappear from future versions.

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.ColumnSelectionForm
member.summary: This form is an example of how an application could allows the user to select which columns an ObjectListView will display, as well as select which order the columns are displayed in.

remarks.para: In Tile view, ColumnHeader.DisplayIndex does nothing. To reorder the columns you have to change the order of objects in the Columns property.
Remember that the first column is special! It has to remain the first column.

member.name: T:DevGrep.Controls.DLV.TypedObjectListView`1
member.summary: A TypedObjectListView is a type-safe wrapper around an ObjectListView.

remarks.para: VCS does not support generics on controls. It can be faked to some degree, but it cannot be completely overcome. In our case in particular, there is no way to create the custom OLVColumn's that we need to truly be generic. So this wrapper is an experiment in providing some type-safe access in a way that is useful and available today.
A TypedObjectListView is not more efficient than a normal ObjectListView. Underneath, the same name of casts are performed. But it is easier to use since you do not have to write the casts yourself.

member.typeparam: The class of model object that the list will manage

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.RibbonHelpers.WinApi.WM_NCLBUTTONDOWN
member.summary: The WM_NCLBUTTONDOWN message is posted when the user presses the left mouse button while the cursor is within the nonclient area of a window.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.RibbonHelpers.WinApi.WM_NCLBUTTONUP
member.summary: The WM_NCLBUTTONUP message is posted when the user releases the left mouse button while the cursor is within the nonclient area of a window.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.RibbonHelpers.WinApi.WM_SIZE
member.summary: The WM_SIZE message is sent to a window after its size has changed.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.RibbonHelpers.WinApi.WM_ERASEBKGND
member.summary: The WM_ERASEBKGND message is sent when the window background must be erased (for example, when a window is resized).

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.RibbonHelpers.WinApi.WM_NCCALCSIZE
member.summary: The WM_NCCALCSIZE message is sent when the size and position of a window's client area must be calculated.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Forms.RibbonHelpers.WinApi.WM_NCHITTEST
